title: Dad shows wife's C-section on Facebook Live to 100,000 people including when she was on operating table
text:
Get daily   
A video blogger dad broadcast his wife's C-section on Facebook to 100,000 people - and even filmed while she was on the operating table. 
Stephen Skinner, 32, hit record just as Holly, 28, was heading to hospital to be induced and was expecting to capture the water birth of their first child on camera. 
But things didn't go to plan and doctors were forced to perform a C-section after the baby's head moved into a sideways position. 
In a series of five videos posted on Facebook via the Channel Mum website, Antarctic guide Stephen and yoga teacher Holly describe their "rollercoaster" labour. The whole Skinner family are united after the birth of their son Atlas (Photo: Channel Mum) 
One clip shows Holly lying in bed in tears while another shows Stephen in full scrubs in an equipment store moments before the C-section is set to get underway. Read More Parents filming time-lapse of pregnancy didn't realise ticking time bomb tumour could have killed mum any second 
Stephen didn't film in the operating theatre but the couple, of Cheshunt, Herts., revealed the gender and name of 9lb 9oz Atlas in a video viewed 20,000 times. 
All the footage was recorded live but was posted to Facebook a few days after the birth, on December 28, as it was happening over the busy Christmas period. 
The clips have been viewed around 100,000 times in total. 
Stephen, who documented Holly's pregnancy and birth on his channel Nomadi Daddy, said: "I feel like the videos were really real and raw. We were not editing life. Stephen Skinner, 32, with his wife Holly (Photo: Channel Mum) 
"We had planned to put a tripod in the corner of the room and film the water birth. I was going to get in the pool with Holly. 
"So when we found out that she was going to have a c-section there was a big part of us that thought, 'This isn't going to work now.' 
"We thought, 'People aren't going to want to watch it,' but in the end it was probably better because it was such an emotional, real thing. Read More Miracle baby born with bowel OUTSIDE her body defies the odds to celebrate first birthday 
"There are difficult points and part of you does think, 'This is real. Put the camera away and focus on it.' 
"But Holly and I are both really happy that we did manage to capture the down moments as well as the high, elated moments. 
"It was very very difficult as some points but the birth was one of the most beautiful things both of us have experienced." Stephen gets ready for action with Holly just about to give birth (Photo: Channel Mum) But it was all worth it as little Atlas as born after an emergency C-section (Photo: Channel Mum) 
Stephen added: "By doing this I was trying to bring some attention to dads and say, 'Hey, us guys work hard too. 
"We are caring and supportive and we cry as well.'" 
Holly said: "There were times when I felt like I didn't really want the camera there but I'm so glad that we have got it to look back on. Read More Christmas baby joy for tragic parents who lost their beloved son at just two days old 
"A lot of it is so blurry for me and watching back I'm like 'Oh my God, we went through so much.' 
"If the camera hadn't have been there I wouldn't have remembered any of it. I've had so many people contacting me to say, 'I wish we'd done that.' 
"I've watched the videos a million times and I cry every single time. 
"It is so amazing that we will have them to keep forever, and I will get to show Atlas one day." Holly with her newborn child after the operation (Photo: Channel Mum) 
The couple added that they hope that sharing their experience will help remove the "taboo" surrounding C-sections. 
Holly said: "The C-section was not what I wanted and when I found out I cried a lot. 
"I was so hooked on this idea of what it should have been, but it was so so much more than I could have asked for. 
"In the end it was never up to me. His life is so precious and he had to come into it safely. 
"There is a massive taboo around C-sections so I want this to show that there is no shame in having one whatsoever." Like us on Facebook
